courses.title: The Design of Everyday Things
courses.description: Based on Don Norman's classic book

content.title: Doors, Handles, and Hidden Messages
text-segments: Every day, objects silently communicate what they want you to do.
A door handle screams 'pull me!' A flat metal plate whispers 'push here.'
In this course, we'll explore three fundamental design principles: affordances, mapping, and feedback.

content.title: Story 1
text-segments: Sarah approaches the hotel door.
Glass panel with a vertical metal plate.
The plate looks like a handle.
Her brain screams "pull this!"
What choice did evolution give her?
She grabs and pulls. Nothing.
Confused, she pushes. The door opens.
This is a Norman door.
It gives the wrong signal.

content.title: Story 2
text-segments: Emma approaches the conference room door.
It's entirely made of glass.
No visible handle, no obvious push point.
The surface is completely smooth.
She pushes where others have pushed.
Smudges on the glass are her only clue.
The door swings open.
Poor affordances left her guessing.
Good design would show her the way.

content.title: Story 3
text-segments: Alex finds a sleek modern water bottle.
The cap looks like it should twist off.
He turns it counterclockwise. Nothing.
He tries clockwise. Still stuck.
Finally, he notices it's a flip-top.
The cap hinges upward, not twist.
The bottle's design suggested the wrong action.
This is what designers call false affordances.
Objects that lie about their function.

content.title: Door Design
content.question: Quick question: When you see a door with a handle, what does your brain assume?
content.explanation: Handles suggest pulling. This is called an "affordance" - what the design tells you to do.
content.hint: Think about what action a handle naturally suggests when you grab it.

content.title: Glass Door Mystery
content.question: Why was Emma confused by the glass door?

options.text: It provided no visual clues about how to open it

content.explanation: The door lacked affordances - visual or physical cues that indicate how it should be used.
content.hint: Consider what visual information the door provided about its operation.

content.title: Water Bottle Confusion
content.question: Why did Alex struggle with the water bottle cap?

options.text: The design suggested twisting when it actually flipped

content.explanation: This is a false affordance - the design suggests one action while requiring another.
content.hint: Think about what action the cap's appearance suggested versus what was actually needed.

content.title: What Are Affordances?
text-segments: Those three scenarios reveal something profound about how objects communicate.
Each confusion wasn't random - it reveals how design shapes our expectations and actions.
Don Norman studied these patterns and identified affordances as a fundamental principle of intuitive design.
Understanding affordances transforms how you see every interface, from door handles to smartphone apps.

content.title: Affordances
text-segments: The first principle is affordances - the relationship between an object's properties and what actions they suggest to users.
A door handle naturally affords grasping and pulling, while a flat metal plate clearly affords pushing.
Good affordances are immediately obvious - you know what to do without thinking or reading instructions.
Poor affordances mislead users into taking wrong actions, creating the illusion of user error when it's actually design failure.

content.title: Types of Affordances
text-segments: Objects can provide different types of affordances to guide user behavior.
Visual affordances use appearance - a raised button looks pressable, a handle looks graspable.
Physical affordances use shape and texture - a groove suggests sliding, ridges suggest gripping.
Cultural affordances rely on learned conventions - red means stop, green means go.

content.title: The USB Mystery
content.question: Why does a USB cable never fit on the first try?

options.text: The USB exists in quantum superposition
Poor visual design makes orientation unclear

content.explanation: USB connectors look identical from both sides. Good design makes orientation obvious.
content.hint: Consider what visual information the USB connector provides to help users orient it correctly.

content.title: Affordances in Practice
text-segments: Great designers use affordances to guide behavior without instruction.
A well-designed slider has a groove that suggests the direction of movement.
Buttons are raised to suggest pressing, while flat areas suggest they're not interactive.
The best affordances feel so natural that you don't even notice them working.

content.title: Affordance Check
content.question: True or false: A good affordance requires written instructions to understand.
content.explanation: False! Good affordances are immediately obvious and require no explanation. If you need instructions, the affordance has failed.
content.hint: Think about the best-designed objects you use - do they need labels?

content.title: Complete the Principle
content.question: Fill in the blanks: Affordances are the _____ between object properties and the _____ they suggest.
content.explanation: Affordances are the relationship between object properties and the actions they suggest. This fundamental definition shows how design communicates function.
content.hint: Think back to Norman's original definition of affordances.

content.title: Design Principle Check
content.question: Good design should require extensive user manuals to understand.
content.explanation: Good design should be intuitive and self-explanatory. If it needs a manual, the design has failed to communicate its function clearly.

content.title: Door Study Results
content.question: In Norman's study of door-related accidents, what percentage of people pulled a push door on their first attempt?
content.explanation: Norman found that 73% of people initially pulled doors that were meant to be pushed when the door had a vertical handle. This demonstrates how powerful affordances are - handles strongly suggest pulling, regardless of signage.

content.title: Affordance Examples
text-segments: Great affordances work invisibly - you use them without thinking.
Scissors have finger holes that show exactly where to place your fingers.
A zipper tab moves up and down along an obvious track.
Good affordances make the correct action feel inevitable and natural.

content.title: Affordances in Your Life
content.prompt: Think about an object you use daily that has excellent affordances. What makes it so intuitive?
thinking-points: What visual or physical cues guide your behavior?
How does the design suggest the correct action?
Would this object work for someone who's never seen it before?
What would happen if the affordances were removed?

content.title: Seeing Affordances Everywhere
text-segments: You now understand how objects silently communicate their purpose.
Every handle, button, and switch tells a story about its intended use.
Good affordances guide you naturally; poor ones leave you guessing.
In our next lesson, we'll explore natural mapping - how controls relate logically to their effects.

content.title: When Controls Make Sense
text-segments: Some controls feel instantly logical, while others leave you guessing.
A steering wheel naturally maps to car direction - turn right to go right.
In this lesson, we'll explore natural mapping - how great design matches your mental expectations.

content.title: Story 1
text-segments: David faces the bathroom faucet.
Two identical handles side by side.
Hot or cold? Left or right?
Which way do you turn for hot water?
There are no labels, no indicators.
He turns the left handle clockwise.
Ice cold water blasts his hands.
The mapping was backwards.
Why should he have to guess?

content.title: Story 2
text-segments: Maria sits in front of the stove.
Four burners, four control knobs.
But which knob controls which burner?
The knobs are arranged in a straight line.
How does that map to a square grid?
She turns the leftmost knob.
The back-right burner ignites.
This violates natural mapping.
The control should match the layout.

content.title: Story 3
text-segments: Tom adjusts his car's side mirrors.
The control panel has four arrow buttons.
Up, down, left, right - simple enough.
He presses up. The mirror tilts down.
He presses right. It moves left.
The controls work in reverse.
His mental model says one thing.
The system does another.
Poor mapping breaks intuition.

content.title: Faucet Mapping
content.question: Why did David struggle with the bathroom faucet?

options.text: The handles had no clear mapping to hot and cold
The water pressure was too high

content.explanation: Without visual cues or natural positioning, users have to guess which control does what. Good mapping makes the relationship obvious.
content.hint: Consider what information was missing from the faucet handles.

content.title: Stove Controls
content.question: What made the stove controls confusing for Maria?

options.text: The knobs were arranged differently than the burners
She wasn't familiar with gas stoves

content.explanation: Linear control layout doesn't match the square burner arrangement - poor spatial mapping forces users to memorize arbitrary relationships.
content.hint: Look at how the controls were positioned compared to the burners.

content.title: Mirror Controls
content.question: What frustrated Tom about the car's mirror controls?

options.text: The controls worked opposite to his expectations

content.explanation: When controls work opposite to natural expectations, they violate users' mental models and force them to think backwards.
content.hint: Think about what direction Tom expected when he pressed 'up'.

content.title: What is Natural Mapping?
text-segments: Those three scenarios reveal a fundamental design principle.
Natural mapping is the relationship between controls and their effects in the world.
Good mapping uses spatial correspondence, cultural conventions, or logical relationships.
When mapping is natural, you don't have to think - the right action feels obvious.

content.title: Natural Mapping
text-segments: Natural mapping takes advantage of physical analogies and cultural standards.
A steering wheel maps rotation directly to direction - turning right makes you go right.
Light switches positioned to mirror room layout create instant understanding.
When mapping violates these relationships, simple tasks require mental translation.

content.title: Types of Mapping
text-segments: Spatial mapping uses physical relationships - controls positioned like their effects.
Cultural mapping relies on learned conventions - red for stop, green for go.
Semantic mapping uses meaning - louder sounds from bigger speakers.
The best mapping combines multiple types for maximum clarity.

content.title: Steering Wheel Success
content.question: Why does a steering wheel feel so natural to use?

options.text: It maps rotation directly to direction
It's the traditional way cars work

content.explanation: Steering wheels work because they provide direct spatial mapping - the direction you turn the wheel corresponds to the direction the car goes.
content.hint: Think about the relationship between wheel movement and car direction.

content.title: Mapping in Practice
text-segments: Great designers arrange controls to match their effects spatially.
Volume controls on the right feel natural because we read left to right.
Elevator buttons arranged vertically match the floors they control.
Good mapping reduces cognitive load and prevents errors.

content.title: Mapping Check
content.question: True or false: Good natural mapping should require learning and practice to understand.
content.explanation: False! Natural mapping should be immediately intuitive, requiring no learning. If users need to practice, the mapping isn't natural enough.
content.hint: Think about what 'natural' means in this context.

content.title: Complete the Principle
content.question: Natural mapping uses _____ correspondence and _____ conventions to make controls intuitive.
content.explanation: Natural mapping uses spatial correspondence (physical relationships) and cultural conventions (learned standards) to create intuitive controls.
content.hint: Think about the two main ways mapping can feel natural to users.

content.title: Mapping Errors
content.question: What percentage of user errors in complex control panels are caused by poor mapping, according to design studies?
content.explanation: Research shows that 65% of errors in complex interfaces stem from poor mapping. When controls don't match user expectations, mistakes are inevitable.
content.hint: Consider how often you press the wrong button when controls aren't where you expect them.

content.title: Mapping Examples
text-segments: Good mapping is everywhere once you notice it.
Car turn signals: left lever for left turn, right lever for right turn.
Piano keys: higher notes to the right, lower notes to the left.
Excellent mapping makes the interface disappear into pure intention.

content.title: Mapping in Your Life
content.prompt: Think about a control interface you use daily that has excellent natural mapping. Why does it work so well?
thinking-points: How do the controls relate spatially to their effects?
What cultural conventions does the design use?
Would this interface work for someone from a different culture?
How would poor mapping make this interface frustrating?

content.title: Mental Models Matter
text-segments: You now understand how great design matches mental expectations.
Natural mapping makes controls feel obvious and prevent errors.
When mapping breaks down, even simple tasks become complex puzzles.
In our next lesson, we'll explore feedback - how systems confirm your actions worked.

content.title: When Silence Speaks Volumes
intro-text-segments: You press a button and... nothing happens. Or does it?
Good feedback confirms your actions immediately and clearly.
In this lesson, we'll explore feedback - how systems communicate what's happening.

content.title: Story 1
text-segments: Lisa stands at the elevator.
She presses the call button.
No light, no sound, no confirmation.
Did it register? She presses again.
And again. Still nothing visible.
Three minutes later, two elevators arrive.
She had called both, unknowingly.
Silent buttons create confusion.
Feedback would have prevented this.

content.title: Story 2
text-segments: Mike submits an online form.
He clicks 'Submit' and waits.
The page doesn't change at all.
Is it processing? Did it work?
He clicks Submit again. Still nothing.
He refreshes and tries once more.
Later, he receives three confirmation emails.
Poor feedback led to triple submission.
Users need to know what's happening.

content.title: Story 3
text-segments: Anna uses her car's touchscreen.
She taps to adjust the temperature.
The screen shows no response.
She taps harder, multiple times.
Suddenly the temperature jumps wildly.
All her taps had registered.
The system was just slow to respond.
Delayed feedback creates frustration.
Immediate acknowledgment is crucial.

content.title: Elevator Confusion
content.question: Why did Lisa end up calling two elevators?

options.text: The button provided no feedback about her actions

content.explanation: Without visual or auditory feedback, Lisa couldn't tell if her button presses were registered. Good feedback would have shown her the call was received.
content.hint: Consider what information Lisa needed after pressing the button.

content.title: Form Submission Problem
content.question: What caused Mike to submit the form three times?

options.text: The system gave no indication that submission was processing

content.explanation: Without feedback showing that the form was being processed, Mike had no way to know his first submission was working. A loading indicator would have prevented this.
content.hint: Think about what Mike needed to see after clicking Submit.

content.title: Touchscreen Frustration
content.question: Why did Anna's temperature adjustment go wrong?

options.text: The system delayed feedback, making her think it wasn't working
She didn't know how to use the system

content.explanation: Delayed feedback broke the connection between action and result. Anna needed immediate acknowledgment that each tap was registered, even if processing took time.
content.hint: Consider the timing between Anna's actions and the system's response.

content.title: What is Feedback?
text-segments: Those three scenarios reveal why feedback is essential for good design.
Feedback is the system's way of communicating with users about their actions.
Good feedback is immediate, informative, and appropriate to the action performed.
Without feedback, users operate blind - never sure if their actions worked.

content.title: The Feedback Loop
text-segments: Every interaction creates a communication loop between user and system.
User acts, system responds, user interprets response, user acts again.
When feedback is missing or unclear, this loop breaks down completely.
Good feedback keeps the conversation flowing smoothly.

content.title: Types of Feedback
text-segments: Visual feedback uses lights, colors, animations, and text changes.
Auditory feedback employs clicks, beeps, and sound effects.
Tactile feedback provides vibration, resistance, or physical response.
The best systems combine multiple feedback types for clarity.

content.title: Keyboard Success
content.question: Why do physical keyboards feel so responsive to use?

options.text: They provide immediate tactile and auditory feedback

content.explanation: Physical keyboards excel because they provide instant tactile feedback when pressed and auditory confirmation through key clicks. You immediately know your action registered.
content.hint: Think about what you feel and hear when you press a key.

content.title: Feedback Timing
text-segments: Feedback timing is crucial for maintaining the action-response connection.
Immediate acknowledgment shows the action was received.
Progress indicators communicate ongoing processes.
Completion signals tell users when tasks finish successfully.

content.title: Feedback Timing
content.question: True or false: Good feedback should only appear when an action is completely finished.
content.explanation: False! Good feedback starts immediately to acknowledge the action, continues during processing to show progress, and confirms completion. Waiting until the end leaves users wondering if anything happened.
content.hint: Think about what users need to know during a long process.

content.title: Complete the Principle
content.question: Good feedback should be _____, _____, and appropriate to the action performed.
content.explanation: Good feedback should be immediate (so users know their action registered) and informative (so they understand what's happening or what to do next).
content.hint: Think about the key qualities that make feedback effective.

content.title: Button Press Research
content.question: What percentage of users will press a button multiple times if they don't receive immediate feedback, according to usability studies?
content.explanation: Studies show that 78% of users will press unresponsive buttons repeatedly within 3 seconds. Without feedback, users assume their action didn't register and try again.
content.hint: Consider how you behave when a button seems unresponsive.

content.title: Feedback Examples
text-segments: Great feedback surrounds us in well-designed interactions.
Button highlights when you hover over them in software.
ATMs beep when you press buttons and show confirmation screens.
Car indicators click rhythmically to confirm they're working.
Excellent feedback makes interaction feel natural and confident.

content.title: Feedback in Your Life
content.prompt: Think about a device or interface you use that provides excellent feedback. What makes the feedback so effective?
thinking-points: What types of feedback does it provide (visual, auditory, tactile)?
How quickly does the feedback appear after your actions?
How does the feedback help you understand what's happening?
What would happen if this feedback was removed?

content.title: The Conversation Continues
text-segments: You now understand how systems should communicate with users.
Good feedback creates confident, efficient interactions.
Poor feedback leads to confusion, errors, and frustration.
You've mastered the three pillars: affordances reveal purpose, mapping creates logic, and feedback confirms action.
